texts.value_en: (x) refers to another special rule that the Aura grants to units around it. This unit and all Friendly Core units while within 6” of it have the (x) special rule. Note an Aura may have a further qualifier, in which case the Aura will only grant the special rule to the unit with that name or keyword in addition to the unit with the Aura itself. Effects of Auras of the same type are not cumulative. So, for instance, a unit covered by two Aura (Thunderous Charge (+1)) do not gain Thunderous Charge (+2). Units only gain special rules that affect melee or ranged combat (such as Brutal, Elite, Crushing Strength etc.) if they are within the Aura when the combat is being resolved. Units only gain special rules that affect movement (such as Pathfinder, Strider, Wild Charge etc.) if they are within the Aura at the beginning of their movement.

If an enemy unit is in base contact with the inside of the castle wall, or the Garrisoning unit cannot be placed in base contact, a unit Garrisoning that wall section may still charge. A Hero is a unit of a single model. It can be an officer, a sorcerer or even a mighty lord of its race. Heroes vary in size between different races, and can ride many types of mount or even monstrous war-beasts, so Heroes always have a tag in brackets specifying what type of unit they belong to. This helps when determining their Height and other special rules that are relevant to that type.
A Monster is a unit of a single model – a large and powerful mythical beast or magical construct.

A Titan is a unit of a single model – a being of both gargantuan size and strength.

A War Engine is a unit of a single machine, like a catapult or bolt thrower. A number of decorative crew models may be arranged around the machine in a suitably entertaining fashion.
A Wavered unit that is engaged on a single flank may disengage by issuing a change facing order and may end the change facing order within 1” of enemy units.
A charging unit must make contact with a wall section if they intend to attack a unit Garrisoning it.

A diverse abundance of terrain becomes more important in smaller games where small imbalances in lists can have a big impact. Perhaps representing a small hamlet, or a farm with outbuildings. As such, it’s recommended that Ambush! games be played on a more terrain-crowded table than would be the case in traditional games. Players should make sure there are few, if any, clear lanes where LoS can be drawn across the entire table, to keep spells and other ranged attacks from dominating the game. Furthermore, blocking terrain and obstacles should be utilized to keep units with the Pathfinder special rule from dominating the playing area.

A firing unit that is currently in base contact with an Obstacle, ignores it for determining whether an enemy unit is an Obscured Target, unless the enemy unit is also in contact with the same Obstacle.

A firing unit that received a Halt order in its Movement phase ignores any piece of Difficult Terrain that it is currently within, or in base contact with, for determining whether an enemy unit is an Obscured Target, unless the enemy unit is also touching or within the same piece of Difficult Terrain.

A good commander is able to bring the best out in their soldiers with expert leadership and tactical acumen. To simulate this we use Command Points to represent your ability to get the most from your army. The number of swords you roll on your Command Dice equates to the Command Points you have and forms your Command Pool. Turning the dice (e.g. 3 to 2, 1 to blank), is a useful way to track the Command Points you are spending.
A maximum of 2 Tower Artillery may be selected in a defending force and do not need to be unlocked by a Regiment, Horde or Legion of ‘regular’ units.
A maximum of 3 Bomb Wagons and 3 Siege Artillery may be chosen in an Attacker’s force but these do not need to be unlocked by a Regiment, Horde or Legion of ‘regular’ units.

A normal castle is comprised of three wall sections and two towers. The walls consist of one front section which must contain a gate/door, and two side sections. While there is no standard castle size, we recommend that each wall section should be roughly 12” length, and have enough space on top to comfortably place a horde of Infantry. For particularly large sieges you may wish to increase the amount of sections used, or play with larger sections. A tower should be placed at each end of the front wall section, they should be roughly the same size as the depth of the walls. Being large enough to support a Troop of Infantry is ideal.

A spellcaster can only purchase a version of the spell up to their spellcaster tier; it can purchase below its tier, but not above. i.e., a tier 1 spellcaster can purchase tier 1 spells, but not tier 2 or 3; whereas a tier 3 spellcaster can purchase tier 1, 2 and 3 spells.

A spellcasting tier is listed in the special rules section of each unit that is capable of casting spells. Tiers give a rough idea of the relative power of any given caster, where a higher number represents a more powerful or knowledgeable sorcerer, and a lower number may represent a novice, or even a unit with a simple innate magical ability. A unit must have a spellcasting tier to be considered a spellcaster. These tiers will be used in future supplements.

A tower may only be Garrisoned by a single Hero (Inf), Hero (Large Inf), Infantry/Heavy Infantry, Troop or Large/ Monstrous Infantry Regiment. The tower itself may not be directly targeted. However, if all adjoining wall sections are Routed (destroyed), the tower, along with any Garrisoning unit, is removed from play and replaced with a suitable obstacle (generally a large pile of rubble!).

A unit from the Attacking side may not move or charge through a gate from the outside of the castle while it is still intact. However, if they charge the front castle wall section and finish their move in base contact with the gate, they may choose to attack it. Unlike a castle wall section, any unit may attack and cause damage to a gate in Melee.
A unit is Engaged when it is in base contact with an enemy unit that it 1) Charged or 2) was Charged by.
A unit may not hold more than one Loot Counter for purposes of scoring.

A unit may only benefit from a single Command Order, including Orders with a persistent effect, per Turn. If a unit could be affected by multiple Orders, it must choose which to benefit from before any actions are made or dice are rolled. All Orders must be declared before any relevant dice are rolled. To use a Command Order on a unit, spend the appropriate Command Point(s) for the Order and then apply the listed effects. Each Command Order only lasts until the End of the current Turn unless otherwise stated.
A unit that is Counter Charging is never Hindered, whether by terrain, special rules or any other reason.

A unit that is Garrisoning a wall section may move to an adjoining empty wall section as its movement order for the Turn - simply pick up the unit and place it in the adjoining section, facing in or out as required. The wall section being moved to must not already be Garrisoned by another unit. Once the unit has moved to the adjoining wall section, it may not make any further moves that Turn.

After a player has completed their Turn, they can choose to destroy any Objective Markers which they control (except for the Central Objective). Repeat this process at the end of each of the player’s Turns until the end of the game. Destroyed Objective Markers are removed from play and have no influence on the rest of the game.

After both players have deployed their forces, each player places one Loot Counter within their deployment area, giving them to a unit to carry if they wish. Roll off to see who places their Loot Counter first. Victory Points can be accumulated from Round three onwards each player scores points at the end of their respective Turn:

After both players have set up their forces, roll a D3. Each player places that many Loot Counters within their set-up area, giving them to units to carry if they wish. Roll of to see who begins placing their Loot Counters frst, and the players take it in turns to place one Loot Counter each until they have placed them all.

After deciding which player begins to set up, start that player’s clock. Once that player has set up their first unit, stop their clock, start their opponent’s clock and so on. Once setup is finished, stop both clocks and roll to see who has the first turn. Once the winner of the roll has made their choice, restart that player’s clock. That player plays a Turn, then stops their clock and activates the opponent’s clock, and so on.

After deployment and all Scout moves have been completed by both players, but before rolling for the first Turn, this unit may be picked up and redeployed anywhere in the controlling player’s deployment zone. If more than one unit shares this rule then pick up all units first, then deploy them. If units on both sides share this rule, both players remove all units with this rule from the board and then take turns deploying them starting with the player who finished their normal deployment first.

After deployment, place one Objective Marker in the exact centre of the Courtyard and then each player, starting with the Attacker, takes turns to place two more Objective Markers on the table, no more than 6” away from the centre line and at least 12” from any other Objective Marker. The Objective Marker in the courtyard is worth 2 points while the other two are worth 1 point each. To successfully complete this objective the Defender must control Objective Markers with a combined worth at least 3 points at the end of the game.

After discarding any dice that missed, pick up the remaining dice that scored hits and roll them again to try and damage the enemy unit. The number your unit needs to damage the target is equal to or greater than the target’s Defence value. This roll can sometimes be modified by special rules, etc.
After moving forwards, Regiment A makes contact with Horde C. It will then align as normal and then shuffle to its final position.

After rolling for the type of game and setting up the objectives/loot, if any, both players roll a die. The person scoring highest chooses one long edge of the battlefield as their own and then places one of their units on that side of the battlefield, more than 12” from the middle line. Their opponent then does the same on the opposite side of the table. The players continue to alternate placing units until they have placed all of their units onto the table in their Set-up areas.

After rolling of to choose sides, place one Objective Marker in the exact centre of the board. The players then place three more Objective Markers 6” from the centre line on their opponent’s half of the board, rolling of to see who places theirs first. Take it in turns until all the Objective Markers have been placed.

After rolling of to choose sides, roll of to see who places the first Bluff Counter. The players take it in turns to place one Bluff Counter of their choice (marked side down) fully on their opponent’s half of the board, following the same placement restrictions as Objective Markers.

After rolling off to choose sides, place one Objective Marker in the exact centre of the board. The players then place three (two for smaller games) more Objective Markers 6” from the centre line on their opponent’s half of the board, rolling off to see who places theirs first. Take it in turns until all the Objective Markers have been placed.

Whether you’re just getting started with the game, you’re an experienced player looking to dabble with a new army before you go all-in, or just looking to play a quick game that fits on your kitchen table, the following rules for playing Kings of War with armies under 1000 points might be what you’re looking for. We call this way of playing Kings of War Ambush!

While Disengaging, if a unit begins its Turn Engaged with one or more Enemy units on a single facing only, it may make a free Withdraw move of 1”, directly away from the unit(s), before carrying out a Charge, Change Facing, Sidestep, Back, or Halt order. The Withdraw move cannot be used to come within 1” of any enemy units and the unit must travel the full 1”. If it is not possible to travel the full 1” or to maintain a 1” distance from all enemy units (including the unit(s) it was engaged with), then a unit may not make a Withdraw move.
While Wavering, this unit may still declare a Counter Charge.
While attacking enemy Individuals in Melee, this unit triples its number of Attacks.

While carrying a Loot Counter, a unit’s speed is reduced to 5 (unless it is less than 5) and it cannot be targeted by the Wind Blast, Enthral, or Surge spells. Additionally, while carrying a Loot Counter, a unit loses the Fly, Ordered March, Nimble, and Wild Charge special rules. If a unit has Wildcharge with a variable value (Such as Wild Charge (D3)) it may roll to determine the value of the rule but may not make use of it unless it drops the Loot Counter as normal.
